conclusion: To find the temperature of the gas in state C, we will use the ideal gas law and the relationship between pressure, volume, and temperature.
State A: P_A = 3 x 10^5 Pa, V_A = 2 x 10^-3 m^3, T_A = 27°C; State B: P_B = 2 x 10^5 Pa, V_B = 2 x 10^-3 m^3; State C: P_C = 2 x 10^5 Pa, V_C = 3 x 10^-3 m^3
Convert temperatures to Kelvin: T_A = 27°C + 273.15 = 300.15 K
Use the ideal gas law for State A: (3 x 10^5 Pa)(2 x 10^-3 m^3) = nR (300.15 K)
Use the ideal gas law for State C: (2 x 10^5 Pa)(3 x 10^-3 m^3) = nR T_C
Substitute nR from State A: 600 = (1.999) T_C => T_C = 600 / 1.999 ≈ 300.15 K
Convert the temperature back to Celsius: T_C = 300.15 K - 273.15 = 27°C
